abstract.text: Large scale genomic analysis of 3067 SARS-1 CoV-2 genomes reveals a clonal geo-distribution 2 and a rich genetic variations of hotspots 3 mutations 4 Abstract 33 In late December 2019, an emerging viral infection COVID-19 was identified in Wuhan, 34 China, and became a global pandemic. Characterization of the genetic variants of SARS-35 CoV-2 is crucial in following and evaluating their spread across countries. In this study, 36 we collected and analyzed 3,067 SARS-CoV-2 genomes isolated from 59 countries during 37 the first three months after the onset of this virus. Using comparative genomics analysis, 38 we traced the profiles of the whole-genome mutations and compared the frequency of each 39 mutation in the studied population. The accumulation of mutations during the epidemic 40 period with their geographic locations was also monitored. The results showed 716 site 41 mutations, of which 457 (64%) had a non-synonymous effect. Frequencies of mutated 42 alleles revealed the presence of 39 recurrent non-synonymous mutations, including 10 43 hotspot mutations with a prevalence higher than 0.10 in this population and distributed in 44 six genes of SARS-CoV-2. The distribution of these recurrent mutations on the world map 45 revealed certain genotypes specific to the geographic location. We also found co-occurring 46 mutations resulting in the presence of several haplotypes. Thus, evolution over time has 47

shown a mechanism of co-accumulation and the phylogenetic analysis of this population 48 indicated that this virus can be divided into 3 clades, including a subgroup-specific to the 49 genomes of the United States. On the other hand, analysis of the selective pressure revealed 50 the presence of several negatively selected residues that could be useful for considerations 51 as therapeutic target design. 52

We have also created an inclusive unified database (http://moroccangenomes.ma/covid/) 53 that lists all of the genetic variants of the SARS-CoV-2 genomes found in this study with 54 phylogeographic analysis around the world. 55 56

Proteins with an identity above 60% and sequence coverage above 75% with an e-value 147 threshold below 1e-5 were used to be considered as significant hits. 148
In this study, we used 3,067 SARS-CoV2 complete genomes collected from GISAID 151 EpiCovTM (update: 02-04-2020) and NCBI (update: 20-03-2020) databases. These strains 152
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 genomes used in this study 150

body_text.text: were isolated from 59 countries (Fig 1A) . The most represented origin was American 153 strains with 783 (25.53%), followed by strains from England, Iceland, and China with 407 (13.27%), 343 (11.18%), 329 (10.73%), respectively. The date of isolation was during the To study and follow the appearance and accumulation of mutations, we traced the profiles 160 of non-synonymous mutations, and we compared their frequency in the studied population. 161
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 genomes used in this study 150

body_text.text: Remarkably, compared to the reference sequence Wuhan-Hu-1/2019, a total of 716 162 mutations were identified, including 457 (64%) non-synonymous and 188 (26%) 163 synonymous mutations. The rest (10%) distributed to the intergenic regions. Focusing on 164 non-synonymous mutations, the analysis of the frequencies of mutated alleles revealed the 165 presence of 39 mutations with a prevalence greater than 0.006 (0.06% of the population), 166
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 genomes used in this study 150

body_text.text: which corresponds to at least 20 / 3,067 SARS-CoV-2 genomes (Fig 2) . 167
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 genomes used in this study 150

body_text.text: These recurring mutations were distributed in six genes with variable frequencies, of which 168 the gene coding for replicase polyprotein (ORF1ab), spike protein, membrane 169 glycoprotein, nucleocapsid phosphoprotein, ORF3a, and ORF8. Overall, ORF1ab harbored 170 more non-synonymous mutations compared to the other five genes with 22 mutations, 171 including three mutations located in NSP12-RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (M4555T, 172 T4847I and T5020I), three in NSP13-helicase (V5661A, P5703L and M5865V), two in 173 NSP5-main proteinase (G3278S and K3353R), two in NSP15-EndoRNAse (I6525T, 174 Ter6668W), two in NSP3-multi domains (A876T and T1246I), one in NSP14-exonuclease 175 (S5932F) and one in NSP4-transmembrane domain 2 (F3071Y). Likewise, spike protein 176 harbored three frequent mutations, including V483A in receptor-binding domain (RBD). 177
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 genomes used in this study 150

body_text.text: The rest of the mutations were found in nucleocapsid phosphoprotein (S193I, S194L, 178 S197L, S202N, R203K and G204R), ORF3a (S193I, S194L, S197L, S202N, R203K and 179 G204R), membrane glycoprotein (D3G and T175M) and ORF8 (V62L and L84S). 180
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 genomes used in this study 150

body_text.text: Interestingly, among all recurrent mutations, ten were found as hotspot mutations with a 182 frequency greater than 0.10 in this study population (Fig 2) . The most represented was
body_text.section: Identification of ten hyper-variable genomic hotspot in SARS-CoV-2 genomes 181

body_text.text: Out of 3067 genomes, only 105 were found to be wild type and were particularly of Chinese containing 22% of the total number of mutations, followed by France and New Zealand 198 with 4% and 2%, respectively. It is interesting to note that among the 59 countries, 26 199 harbored singleton mutations. Table S2 illustrates the detailed singleton mutations found 200 in these countries. The majority of the genomes analyzed carried more than one mutation. 201
body_text.section: Geographical distribution and origin of mutations worldwide 191

body_text.text: However, among the recurrent non-synonymous, synonymous and intergenic mutations 202 (Fig 3) . We found G251V (in ORF3a), L84S (in ORF8) and S5932F (in ORF1ab) present 203 on all continents except Africa and Austria (Fig 4) . While F924F, L4715L (in orf1ab), 204 D614G (in spike) and an intergenic variant at position 241 appeared in all strains except 205 those from Asia. In Algeria, the genomes harbored mutations very similar to those in 206
body_text.section: Geographical distribution and origin of mutations worldwide 191

body_text.text: Europe, including two recurrent mutations T265I and Q57H of the ORF3a. Likewise, the 207

body_text.text: European and Dutch genomes also shared ten recurrent mutations. On the other hand, 208 continent-specific mutations have also been observed, for example in America, we found Spike proteins respectively were introduced into the virus for the first time in late February. 233
body_text.section: Geographical distribution and origin of mutations worldwide 191

body_text.text: The phylogenetic tree based on the whole genome alignment showed the presence of 3 235 different clades (Fig S1) and demonstrate that SARS-CoV-2 is wildly disseminated across 236 distinct geographical location. The results showed that several strains are closely related 237 even though they belong to different countries. Which indicate likely transfer events and 238 identify routes for geographical dissemination. For phylogenetic tree 239 Table 1) . 251

The modelling results of ORF1ab showed that the sites with positive selections were 252 distributed in NSP3 and NSP4. While the negatively selected codons were located in NSP3, 253 NSP4, NSP6, NSP12, NSP13, NSP14 and NSP16 (Fig 6) . Thus, only one negatively 254 selected amino acid residue was observed on the receptor binding domain, suggesting that 255 there was no strong selective pressure in the region (Fig 7) . 256

It is interesting to note that among all the strains used of BetaCoronavirus, the ORF8 269 protein was found in orthology only between SARS-RATG13 and SARS-CoV-2. In 270 addition, the ORF10 protein was found as a singleton for SARS-CoV-2. While, the analysis 271 of the pangenome at the intra-genomic scale of 83 isolates of SARS-CoV-2 (Fig 8B) , 272

showed that ORF7b and ORF10 were two accessory proteins (proteins variable) in SARS- In this study, we have defined 3 major clades. The clustering of these genomes revealed 327 the spread of clades to diverse geographical regions. We observed an increase of mutations 328 over time following the first dissemination event from China. Specific haplotypes were 329 also predominant to a geographical location, especially in the US. This study opens up new 330 perspectives to determine whether one of these frequent mutations will lead to biological 331 differences and their correlation with different mortality rates. FIGREF0.text: Introduction used for the analysis. The selected nucleotide sequences of each dataset were aligned using (16) and MEME (Mixed Effects Model of Evolution) (17). For all the methods, values 130 supplied by default were used for statistical confirmation and the overall ω value was 131 calculated according to ML trees under General Time Reversible Model (GTR model). The 132 CI-TASSER generated models (https: //zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu / COVID-19 /) of 133 ORF1ab nonstructural proteins (NSP) 3,4,6,12,13,14 and 16 were used to highlight the 134 sites under selective pressure on the protein, due to the lack of their experimental structures 135 and the absence of suitable templates for homology modelling. On the other hand, the cryo-136 EM structure with PDB id 6VSB was used as a model for the gene S in its prefusion 137 conformation. Structure visualization and image rendering were performed in PyMOL 2.3 138 (Schrodinger LLC). 139 Pangenome construction 140 115 proteomes of the genus Betacorononavirus were obtained from the NCBI database 141 (update: 20-03-2020), of which 83 genomes belonged to the SARS-CoV-2 species and the 142 rest distributed to other species of the same genus publicly available. These proteomes were 143 used for the construction of pangenome at the inter-specific scale of Betacoronavirus and 144 intra-genomic of SARS-CoV-2. In addition, two mutations at positions 210 28117 and 28144 were shared by the Asian genomes, while four different positions 1059, 211 14408, 23403, 25563 and 1397, 11083, 28674, 29742 were shared by African and 212 Australian genomes (Supplementary material). The majority of these mutations are 213 considered to be transition mutations with a high ratio of A substituted by G. The genome appearance of this virus (December 24 to March 25). We have noticed that the mutations 219 have accumulated at a relatively constant rate (Fig 5). The strains selected at the end of 220 March showed a slight increase in the accumulation of mutations with an average of 11.34 221 mutations per genome, compared to the gnomes of February, December and January with 222 an average number of mutations of 9.26, 10.59 10.34 respectively. The linear curve in suggests a continuous accumulation of SNPs in the SARS-CoV-2 genomes in the 224 coming months. This pointed out that many countries had multiple entries for this virus 225 that could be claimed. Thus in the deduced network demonstrated transmission routes in 226 different countries. 227 The study of the accumulation of mutations over time showed a higher number of 228 mutations in the middle of the outbreak (end of January). At the same time, an increase in 229 the number of mutations in early April was also observed. The first mutations to appear 230 were mainly located in the intergenic region linked to the nucleocapsid phosphoprotein and 231 the orf8 protein. The T265I, D614G and L84S hotspot mutations located in orf1ab and 232

FIGREF5.text: 273 CoV-2 genomes, while the other proteins belonged to the core proteins of SARS-CoV-2 274 (conserved in all genomes). of SARS-CoV-2 infection. In this study, we characterized the genetic variations in a large 282 population of SARS-CoV-2 genomes (3,067). Our results showed a diversity of mutations 283 detected with different frequencies. Overall, more than 450 non-synonymous mutations in 284 SARS-CoV-2 genomes have been identified. The orf1ab gene contains 16 non-structural 285 proteins (NSP1-NSP16) (22), and harbored more than 50 % of the frequent mutations, with 286 a high mutation number 117, 61, and 61 in the NSP3, NSP12, and NSP2 Respectively. 287 Both NSP2 and NSP3 were reported to be essential for correcting virus replication errors 288 (23). On the other, hand recent studies have suggested that mutations falling in the 289 endosome-associated-protein-like domain of the NSP2 protein, could explain why this 290 virus is more contagious than SARS (24). The Replication enzymes NSP12 to NSP16 have 291 been reported as antiviral targets for SARS-CoV (25). In the SARS-CoV-2 genomes, we 292 found that NSP12 to NSP15 harbored nine recurrent non-synonymous mutations. Among 293 them, eight identified as new mutations, including three (M4555T, T4847I, T5020I) in 294 NSP12-RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, three (V5661A, P5703L and M5865V) in 295 NSP13-Helicase, two (I6525T, Ter6668W) in NSP15-EndoRNAse. However, these new 296 mutations must be taken into account when developing a vaccine using the ORF1ab protein 297 sequences as a therapeutic target. 298 A high number of mutations were identified in the spike protein, an important determinant 299 in pathogenicity that allows the virion attachment to the cell membrane by interacting with 300 the host ACE2 receptor (26). Among all the frequent mutations in this protein, the V483A 301 mutation has been identified in this receptor and found mainly in SARS-CoV-2 genomes 302 isolated from USA. This result is consistent with the study of Junxian et al. (27). Eight 303 stains from china, USA and France harbored V367F mutation previously described to 304 enhance the affinity with ACE2 receptor (27). genes harboring hotspot mutations belong to the core genome. 312 Thus, under normal circumstances genomic variation increase the viruses spread and 313 pathogenicity. This happens when the virus accumulated mutation enables its virulence 314 potential (29). Genomic comparison of the studied population allowed us to gain insights 315 into virus mutations occurrence over time and within different geographic areas. In the 316 SARS-CoV virus, the SNP distribution is not random, and it is more dominant in critical 317 genes for the virus. As it was already found in many studies (20,30). Our results confirmed 318 what was previously described and elucidate the presence of numerous hotspot mutations. 319Besides, Co-occurrence mutations were also common in different countries all along with 320 singleton mutations. In the case of the USA, the singleton mutations are driven by the single 321 group that diverged differently due to the environment, the host, and the number of 322 generations. These mutations are due to the low fidelity of reverse transcriptase (29, 31). 323Spain, Italy, and the US contain a high number of specific mutations which may be the 324 cause of a rapid transmission, especially in the US. These specific mutations may also be 325 correlated with the critical condition in Italy and Spain. 326

FIGREF6.text: 332 Among the 7 proteins of orf1ab that harbored sites under selective pressure, only NSP3 333 and NSP4 contains both residues under positive and negative selection. The modelling of context of a SARS-CoV replicon (33). However, it could counteract the host's innate 338 immune response (34). It was proposed that the 3Ecto luminal domain of NSP3 interacts 339 with the large luminal domain of NSP4 (residues 112-164) to "zip" the ER membrane and 340 induce discrete membrane formations as an important step in the generation of ER viral 341 replication organelles (35, 36). As we have shown previously by the FEL, MEME and 342 FUBAR methods, the orf1ab 2244 site coding for ILE-1426 is under positive selection 343 pressure and since it is located on the luminal 3ecto domain of the NSP3 protein, this can 344 be explained by a possible host influence on the virus in this domain.The results of selective 345 pressure analysis revealed the presence of several negatively selected residues, one of 346 which is located at the receptor-binding domain (GLN-474) and which is known by its 347 interaction with the GLN24 residue of the human ACE2 (Angiotensin-converting enzyme 3482) receptor (37). In general, it is well-known that negatively selected sites could indicate a 349 functional constraint and could be useful for drug or vaccine target design, given their 350 conserved nature and therefore less likely to change (38). 351 352Conclusion 353The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has caused a very large impact on health and economy 354 worldwide. Therefore, understanding genetic diversity and virus evolution become a 355 priority in the fight against the disease. Our results show several molecular facets of the 356 relevance of this virus. We identified ten non-synonymous hotspot mutations distributed 357 in six of the virus genes with high frequencies of mutated alleles. We also were able to 358 highlight an increase in mutations accumulation overtime and revealed the existence of 359 three major clades in various geographic regions. Finally, the study allowed us to identify 360 specific haplotypes by geographic location and provides a list of sites under selective 361 pressure that could serve as an interesting avenue for future studies.362 363 shared the full genome data for SARS-CoV-2 in the GISAID database.
